NARRATOR: Skin
effect-- describes

the tendency for high
frequency currents

to be near surfaces
of conductors.

Skin effect does not involve
electromagnetic waves.

But it's rather a magnetic
diffusion phenomenon.

One dimensional
magnetic diffusion

can be pictured as
the result of driving

a current from this source
through this metal slab.

To make the current density
and magnetic field intensity
depend only on x.

This configuration calls for
the use of parallel plates

that make electrical
contact with a slab.
The current is alternating.

At very low frequencies, the
resulting current density

in the slab is uniform, and
the magnetic field intensity
is a linear function of x.

At low frequencies,
the magnetic field

falls from the current
imposed by the source
to 0 At the insulating end.
B is the thickness of the slab.
Delta is the skin depth.
Omega is the angular frequency.

The skin depth is inversely
proportional to the square root
of the frequency.

Mu is the permeability,
and sigma is
the conductivity of the slab.

A high frequency implies
a short skin depth.

As the frequency is raised,
so that the skin depth becomes

shorter than the
length of the slab,

the field decay is more
rapid than a linear decay.

This decay reflects the fact
that the current density

is crowding to the edge of the
conductor, nearest the source.

The current density is
distributing itself,

so as to lower the
magnetic flux enclosed
by an average current loop.

To demonstrate this
phenomenon, the slab
is this section of aluminum.

Rather than trying to find
conducting sheets that

are even more conducting
than the aluminum,

we extend this slab
in the y direction

and make it the secondary
of a transformer.
Here's the transformer primary.
Here's the transformer core.

The aluminum is the secondary
of a step down transformer.

In effect, the secondary
is composed of one turn
that is shorted on itself.

We will use this
transverse probe

to measure the distribution
of flux density.
Here's the experiment.

The section where
essentially one

dimensional magnetic
diffusion occurs is here.

By making the conductor
long in the y direction,

we provide enough length
for the current distribution

to become primarily dependent
on x over the middle cross
section.

To avoid an influence of the
magnetic core on the field

distribution here at the
center, we placed it to one end.

This transfers probe
can be inserted

so that it samples the vertical
magnetic field intensity
over the span of the conductor.

The field component normal to
the flat phase is measured.

The slit is little more than
large enough for the probe.

The top trace is the current in
the primary of the transformer,
the driving current.

The bottom trace is the probe
signal, the magnetic flux
density.

As we pull the probe out, we see
the field distribution with x.
The frequency is 60 hertz.

Here, we're at 3 centimeters,
half the slab thickness.

It appears that the
decay is somewhat more
rapid than linear.

So it looks like the
skin depth at 60 hertz

is less than the
thickness of the aluminum.

Let's evaluate the skin depth
in aluminum at 60 hertz.

Aluminum has the
permeability of free space,

a conductivity of 3.5 times
10 to the seventh siemens
per meter.

So at a frequency of 60
hertz, the skin depth

is less than the
conductor thickness.

The skin depth of
1.1 centimeters

is small compared to a conductor
thickness of 6 centimeters.

Here's a prediction
of the field decay,

with distance from the
left edge of the conductor.
This curve is for 60 hertz.

In going from 0 to 1 centimeter
here on the 60 hertz curve,

we should see the
field decay by 40%.

If we measure decays to about
50% of its original value.

Remember, the skin
death is inversely

proportional to the square
root of the frequency.

So if we increase the
frequency to 240 hertz,

4 times the frequency, the
skin depth is half as much,

and the decay should
be more rapid.
This is the decay at 60 hertz.
Here, we're at 1 centimeter.
Here, we're at 3 centimeters.

Now we raise the
frequency to 240 hertz.
This is the decay at 240 hertz.
1 centimeter, 3 centimeters.

The decay at 1 centimeter and
240 hertz plots like this.

These are additional
data points.

Here's the major decay at
240 hertz, here at 60 hertz.

The discrepancy is probably
due to the finite length

of the aluminum in the direction
of current circulation.

Our one dimensional
theory strictly

applies only where the currents
have had sufficient development
length.

When the skin depth is short
compared to the conductor

thickness, the
current distribution
takes the form of a wave.

We've been observing
the decay of this wave.

There's also a
phase shift with x,

caused by the propagation
of this diffusion wave
into the conductor.

By looking at the probe
signal on an oscilloscope,

we can see this phase shift
as the probe is withdrawn.

The top trace is the
excitation current.

The bottom one
the probe current.
Sync to the excitation current.
The frequency is 240 hertz.

So as the probe is withdrawn,
the field decays rapidly.

To see the phase
shift associated

with the propagation,
let's put the probe signal
on top of the driving signal.

Watch the position of a
peak in the probe signal,

relative to that of
the driving current,
as the probe is withdrawn.

As the probe is pulled
into the conductor,

it measures a field that is
increasingly delayed in phase.

The magnitude of the
magnetic diffusion wave

decays exponentially
into the conductor,

with a decay length
that is the skin depth.

The phase shift shows that
the wave has phases that
propagate into the conductor.
